bib.title: Quality of urban climate adaptation plans over time
bib.author: Diana Reckien and Attila Buzasi and Marta Olazabal and Niki-Artemis Spyridaki and Peter Eckersley and Sofia G Simoes and Monica Salvia and Filomena Pietrapertosa and Paris Fokaides and Sascha M Goonesekera and Léa Tardieu and Mario V Balzan and Cheryl L de Boer and Sonia De Gregorio Hurtado and Efrén Feliu and Alexandros Flamos and Aoife Foley and Davide Geneletti and Stelios Grafakos and Oliver Heidrich and Byron Ioannou and Anna Krook-Riekkola and Marko Matosovic and Hans Orru and Kati Orru and Ivan Paspaldzhiev and Klavdija Rižnar and Magdalena Smigaj and Maria Szalmáné Csete and Vincent Viguié and Anja Wejs
bib.abstract: Defining and measuring progress in adaptation are important questions for climate adaptation science, policy, and practice. Here, we assess the progress of urban adaptation planning in 327 European cities between 2005 and 2020 using three ‘ADAptation plan Quality Assessment’ indices, called ADAQA-1/ 2/ 3, that combine six plan quality principles. Half of the cities have an adaptation plan and its quality significantly increased over time. However, generally, plan quality is still low in many cities. Participation and monitoring and evaluation are particularly weak aspects in urban adaptation policy, together with plan ‘consistency’. Consistency connects impacts and vulnerabilities with adaptation goals, planned measures, actions, monitoring and evaluation, and participation processes.
